description: From Middle English rewe, reowe, from Old English hrēow (“sorrow, regret, penitence, repentance, penance”), from Proto-West Germanic *hreuwu (“pain, sadness, regret, repentance”). Compare German reuen (“to regret, to repent”).

From Middle English rewen, ruwen, ruen, reowen, from Old English hrēowan (“to rue; make sorry; grieve”), perhaps influenced by Old Norse hryggja (“to distress, grieve”), from Proto-Germanic *hrewwaną (“to sadden; repent”).

verbs.description: rue (third-person singular simple present rues, present participle ruing or rueing, simple past and past participle rued)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To cause to repent of sin or regret some past action.
(obsolete, transitive) To cause to feel sorrow or pity.
(transitive) To repent of or regret (some past action or event); to wish that a past action or event had not taken place.
examples: I rued the day I crossed paths with her.

entries.meaning: (archaic, intransitive) To feel compassion or pity.
examples: Madame, reweth upon my peynes smerte

entries.meaning: (archaic, intransitive) To feel sorrow or regret.

description: From Middle English rue, from Anglo-Norman ruwe, Old French rue, from Latin rūta, from Ancient Greek ῥυτή (rhutḗ).

entries.meaning: Any of various perennial shrubs of the genus Ruta, especially the herb Ruta graveolens (common rue), formerly used in medicines.
